Articles.Content:
It could mean a number of different things, depending on the context

Mn on the periodic table would be Manganese.

MN could be an abbreviation for the state of Minnesota.

Also, could mean megaNewton or milliNewton (measurements of force, I believe)

Edit:

> 
> Meganewton is MN and millinewton is mN.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-05-18T20:55:16Z" title="05/18/2015 08:55  PM" data-short="9 yr">May 18, 2015</time> by Slam\_Jones**

In what context?

Anyway, here's a list of some candidates

[http://www.abbreviations.com/MN](http://www.abbreviations.com/MN)

Edit: Got beaten to it

> 
> ...
> Mn on the periodic table would be Magnesium.
> 
> ...

Almost. Magnesium is Mg. Manganese is Mn.

> 
> It could mean a number of different things, depending on the context
> Mn on the periodic table would be Magnesium.
> 
> MN could be an abbreviation for the state of Minnesota.
> 
> Also, could mean megaNewton or milliNewton (measurements of force, I believe)

Magnesium is Mg.

Meganewton is MN and millinewton is mN.

> 
> Almost. Magnesium is Mg. Manganese is Mn.

I stand corrected.
Thx I was talking about thrust
